div1.head: Letter from L.O. Howard to Howard A. Kelly, October 31, 1906
div1.opener:
COPY
FROM L. O. HOWARD
OR LUCY HOWARD
October 31, 1906.
My Dear Doctor Kelly:
div1.p:
I have just returned from a long western trip,
and find the complimentary copy of your admirable little book entitled
“Walter Reed and Yellow Fever.” I have glanced over it, and promise
myself the pleasure of a most careful reading in the near future.
It was very kind of you to have this book sent to me. I should
certainly have purchased it otherwise. I congratulate you on having
done an excellent and most careful piece of work, and I am glad that
Doctor Reed had so able and so enthusiastic a biographer. Very few
people -- possibly none outside of the medical profession -- are in po-
sition to appreciate the tremenduous effects of Doctor Reed's work and
the careful manner in which it was performed, and the genius of the
man himself, better than I. As you may not know, I was closely in
touch with the work from its very conception. Doctor Lazear called
on me and talked mosquitoes with me before he went to Cuba. Reed and
Carroll came frequently to my office and studied mosquitoes -- one after-
noon Coquillett and I have them regular class work on the characters
used in distinguishing the different species. After Reed achieved
his first results he wrote me a long letter, which I shall always pre-
serve, in which he described his work and in which his enthusiasm
glowed. One of his expressions I remember was “And now, thanks to
Howard and kerosene, we have yellow fever under control.” I shall
always think, moreover, with peculiar gratification that it was my
story of Reed and his work at that dinner at Graham Bell's that start-
ed the resolution for the Reed memorial. It was an interesting and
eventful dinner. Some of the best men of this country were there, and
my friend, James Fletcher, from Canada. Although it was a large din-
ner, as always happens at Doctor Bell's, the conversation after dinner
was directed by him into single channels, and among other people of
whom he asked questions, he asked me to tell the story of Reed. I
have always hoped that it was the enthusiastic way in which I stated
the subject that started the strong feeling among those present, most
of whom knew only the newspaper comments.

Reed was a great man, and a fine man, and one of the most de-
lightful, sincere and clean personalities I ever met.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, (Signed) L. O. HOWARD. Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
Medical College, Johns Hopkins University,
Baltimore, Md.
